Title:
Cercospora seminalis appears sexually reproducing and
phylogenetically closer to Curvularia species
Keywords:
AFLP, Buchloe dactyloides, Cercospora seminalis, false
smut, ITS, phylogeny
Abstract:
False smut caused by Cercospora seminalis is an important
disease of buffalograss (Buchloe dactyloides) seed production. The
pathogen prevents seed development and causes considerable loss of yield
and reduced germination of buffalograss seed. The current taxonomic
placement of false smut under the Cercospora genus is incorrect based
off of morphological characteristics of the pathogen and molecular
sequence data presented herein. Prior classification has proven to be
uncertain since no known sexual stage has been identified for the
pathogen. The objectives of this study were to determine the
phylogenetic position of the false smut pathogen based on sequence
analysis of the internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region and to infer
the method of reproduction based on amplified fragment length
polymorphic (AFLP) markers. A collection of 86 C. seminalis isolates
were made from six buffalograss sites near Lincoln, Nebraska. Analysis
of the ITS sequences grouped isolates of C. seminalis more closely with
Curvularia species (Teleomorph: Cochliobolus) than to other members of
Cercospora. In total, 481 AFLP DNA markers were scored across all
isolates. All of the markers were polymorphic for the isolates. The
dendrogram constructed by the unweighted pair‐grouped method with
arithmetic average (UPGMA) clustered isolates into numerous groups and
stand‐alone isolates. Analysis of similarities (ANOSIM) test did not
show any significantly different clusters. The high level of genetic
heterogeneity of the fungus suggests that it reproduces sexually rather
than clonally. This also explains why there was no relationship between
the isolate geographic origin and the UPGMA clusters. Further
characterization of C. seminalis is needed to understand its proper
taxonomic position.
